newsitem.title: USA: Circuit City reports lower profits despite higher sales.
newsitem.headline: Circuit City reports lower profits despite higher sales.

text.p: Circuit City Stores Inc. Monday reported a drop in profits for the latest quarter despite a 15 percent jump in sales, citing a challenging environment in the consumer electronics retailing business.

The company, the nation's largest retailer of consumer electronics and major appliances, said it earned $12.5 million, or 13 cents a share, in its fiscal first quarter ended on May 31, down from year-earlier earnings of $16.8 million, or 17 cents a share.
Sales rose to $1.86 billion from $1.62 billion.

"While other consumer electronics retailers have closed stores or curtailed their expansion plans, our successful track record has positioned Circuit City for continued growth despite the currently soft industry conditions," said Richard Sharp, chairman and chief executive officer.
"Nevertheless, our sales trends also reflect a challenging industry environment," he said.
Sharp said personal computer sales were strong initially in the first quarter but they slackened in the final month of the period.
Sales of audio and video product were soft throughout the quarter.
Circuit City's stock was off 37.5 cents at $35.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.
